title: What is Kirillov's belief about the existence of God and its implications for human beings?
first_phrase: This text explores the concept of believing in God and how it affects the understanding of the world. The author argues against Dostoyevsky's projection of the era of "believing" as a collective situation of humanity and suggests that it is more reasonable to consider it as an inner situation. The text mentions the theologians' attempts to explain the irrationality of life and the existence of a supreme rationality. It then introduces Kirillov, who declares that he doesn't believe in God and concludes that if God doesn't exist, then he is God. This part of the text delves into the complexities of the idea of God and self-identity.

Ma la fede può spegnersi, ed allora le cose si com plicano: le mani brancolano nel vuoto. È appunto Kiril lov che si sveglia e dichiara: « Non voglio credere. Io so che Dio non esiste e che non può esistere ». last_phrase: In conclusion, recognizing the absence of a higher power without acknowledging our own godliness is illogical and futile. Kirillov's realization highlights the importance of finding purpose within oneself to avoid collapsing like a wheel without a hub. Fear and suffering may arise, but embracing our divine potential is the only way to fill the void and find true meaning.
